journal-meta.journal-title: Journal of Intelligent Material Systems and Structures

title-group.article-title: Modelling the friction contact in an inertia motor

contrib-group.aff: Mechatronics and Dynamics, Faculty of Mechanical Engineering, University of Paderborn, Paderborn, Germany

author-notes.corresp: Matthias Hunstig, Mechatronics and Dynamics, Faculty of Mechanical Engineering, University of Paderborn, Pohlweg 47-49, 33098 Paderborn, Germany. Email: matthias.hunstig@upb.de

article-meta.issue-title: Special Issue – 6th Annual Energy Harvesting Workshop (EHW), The Hotel Roanoke and Conference Center, Roanoke, Virginia, August 7 – 11, 2011

abstract.p: Piezoelectric inertia motors, also known as stick–slip drives or (smooth) impact drives, use the inertia of a body to drive it by a friction contact in small steps, in the majority of motors composed of a stick phase and a slip phase between the friction partners. For optimizing inertia motors, it is important to understand the friction contact correctly and to measure its properties appropriately. This contribution presents experimental set-ups for measuring the contact force, friction force and relative displacement in an actual inertia motor with a dry friction contact and numerical simulations of the motor operation. The motor uses a pre-stressed multilayer actuator with a displacement in the range of 20 µm. It is shown that a previously postulated condition for the applicability of simple kinetic friction models is well fulfilled for the investigated motor. The friction contact in the motor is simulated using different kinetic friction models. The input for the friction models is the measured motion of the rod. The models qualitatively reproduce the measured motion but show quantitative deviations varying with frequency. These can be explained by vibrations of the driving rod that are experimentally investigated.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The vast majority of piezoelectric motor principles and all commercialized piezoelectric motors use a solid friction contact for driving. For travelling and standing wave motors, this friction contact has been investigated by many researchers. The friction contacts in these motor types seem to be fundamentally different at first glance but can be described using similar models. A good literature survey can be found in the article by Wallaschek (1998).

Inertia motors, also known as stick–slip drives or (smooth) impact drives, are a third type of piezoelectric motors. They make use of the inertia of a body to drive it by a friction contact in small steps, in the majority of motors composed of a stick phase and a slip phase between the friction partners. Figure 1 illustrates the operation principle of the type of inertia motor investigated in this contribution, where a slider is moved along a driving rod by alternating phases of stick and slip. Inertia motors have a simple construction and are controlled by a single driving signal, which allows for low production costs and simplifies miniaturization. Originally developed for high-precision microscopy applications parallelly by Anders et al. (1987), Higuchi et al. (1987) and Pohl (1987), inertia motors are nowadays also used in consumer applications like zoom lenses for cameras in mobile phones (Bansevicius and Blechertas, 2008; Matsusaka et al., 2007; Uchino, 2008).

caption.p: Schematic operation principle of the investigated type of inertia motor.

sec.p:
To date, little research has been conducted on the friction contact in inertia motors. Altpeter (1999) states that the step size is a determining factor deciding whether a kinetic friction model, that is, a model assuming that the friction coefficient is a unique function of the relative velocity in the friction contact, is accurate enough to model an inertia motor. He defines a ‘characteristic displacement’
s
as

where
F
s
is the break-away force and
σ
0
is the tangential stiffness of the friction contact at rest. Altpeter concludes that for motors where the actuator displacement is in the same order of magnitude as
s
or smaller, kinetic friction models are insufficient. On the other hand, they would be sufficient for motors with larger actuator displacements.

Most authors use simple Coulomb friction models with or without static friction (‘stiction’) for modelling the friction contact in inertia motors. Two deviations between these models and experimental data have been reported repeatedly: While the models predict the motor motion very well at low step frequencies, they often fail at higher frequencies, shown for example by Büchi (1996), Van der Wulp (1997) and Okamoto and Yoshida (1998). This deviation cannot clearly be attributed to the friction model but can also be caused by other simplifications used in the motor model, such as neglecting undesired vibrations. The second common deviation is that the minimum voltage, that is, the minimum displacement amplitude of the piezoelectric actuator necessary to drive the motor, is significantly higher than predicted, documented already by Pohl (1987) and later by Van der Wulp (1997), Edeler et al. (2011) and others. This deviation could indeed be caused by the friction model and would then support Altpeter’s these of a characteristic displacement: As the actuator displacement is reduced, it approaches the characteristic displacement, and the deficiencies of the Coulomb friction model become more relevant for the motor operation. For non-resonant inertia motors with variable velocity, it can therefore be reasonable to modify the frequency of the driving signal rather than its amplitude, which can also be advantageous from a control point of view (Hunstig and Hemsel, 2010a).

All studies known to the authors that have so far investigated the friction contact in inertia motors in more detail and see the necessity for more sophisticated friction models like the LuGre model (Canudas de Wit et al., 1995) concentrate on motors with a step size in the nanometre range (Altpeter, 1999; Breguet, 1998; Edeler et al., 2011; Van der Wulp, 1997). To the authors’ knowledge, only Peng and Chen (2011) have recently applied the elastoplastic friction model (Dupont et al., 2002) for modelling an inertia drive with a step size in the range of 10 µm, but they have not investigated possible advantages of the used friction model over a classic Coulomb model, so Altpeter’s thesis on characteristic displacement still stands unrefuted.

In this contribution, experimental setups for measuring the contact force, friction force and relative displacement in an actual inertia motor with a dry friction contact are presented. The motor uses a pre-stressed multilayer actuator that has a displacement in the range of 20 µm. It is shown that Altpeter’s condition for using a kinetic friction model is well fulfilled for the investigated motor. The friction contact in the motor is simulated using different simple kinetic friction models. The input for the friction model is the measured motion of the rod. The experimental parameter identification is described in section ‘Measurements’, the numerical simulation is presented in section ‘Numerical simulation’, and experimental and simulated results are compared in section ‘Comparison of simulation and experimental results’. All investigated friction models qualitatively reproduce the measured motion, but show quantitative deviations that vary for different excitation frequencies. An investigation of the vibration shape of the driving rod documented in section ‘Measurement of rod vibration’ shows the likely reason for this: The displacement in axial direction is not constant along the rod, and there are lateral vibrations influencing the contact force and therefore the slider motion that cannot be represented in the applied numerical model.

sec.title: Investigated motor
sec.p:
The motor investigated in this article, as shown in Figure 2, has been built for fundamental investigations of friction and inertia motor control. Its operation has been investigated in detail, for example, by Hunstig and Hemsel (2010a, 2010b) and Hunstig et al. (2010). It is based on a pre-stressed multilayer actuator (PSt 150/5/20 from Piezomechanik GmbH) with a stated capacitance of 800 nF, a length of 28 mm and a maximum stroke of 27 µm. The pre-stress in the actuator is produced by a stack of disc springs. Attached to the piezoelectric actuator is a steel rod. An aluminium slider with exchangeable friction pads and attachable weights move along the rod. It is pressed against the rod by a variable number of magnets. This construction allows for almost free and generally independent variation of most design parameters. The motor can be mounted at arbitrary slope angles
α
. Horizontal operation with the slider on top of the rod is defined as
α =
0
∘
, and vertical operation with the rod pointing up is defined as
α =
90
∘
, as shown in Figure 3. Figure 3 also introduces the coordinate system
( x , y , z )
where
x
points to the axial direction of the driving rod and
z
points from the rod towards the slider.

caption.p:
Orientation of the motor for different values of
α
.

sec.title: Measurement of normal force
sec.p: For direct measurement of the normal force in the friction contact, it would be necessary to manipulate the parts under investigation and, for example, integrate a force sensor in one of them. Because the applied measurement method shall be independent of motor design, the contact force is measured by applying a slowly increasing lift-off force opposing the contact force and detecting when the two forces cancel each other out.

sec.title: Experimental setup
sec.p: Figure 4 shows the setup for the normal force measurement. Using a specially designed tool, the slider was slowly lifted off the driving rod by operating a manual positioning stage. The applied force was measured using a force sensor (PW4C3/300G-1 from Hottinger Baldwin Messtechnik GmbH, Germany) connected to a data acquisition system.

caption.p: Setup for measuring the normal force; inset shows computer aided design (CAD) detail of driving rod, slider and lift-off tool.

sec.title: Calculation
sec.p:
Figure 5 shows the forces acting on the slider, assuming that the total contact force between driving rod and slider is equally distributed between the two contacts.
F
n
is the normal force at one of these contacts.
F
z
is the total force pressing the slider against the driving rod. It is composed of the magnetic attraction force
F
m
and the weight of the slider perpendicular to the rod:

caption.p: Schematic representation of forces between driving rod, slider and lift-off tool.

sec.p:
where
m
s
is the mass of the slider and
g
is the gravitational acceleration.
F
o
is the force exerted by the lift-off tool and measured by the sensor.

Without the lift-off tool, that is, for
F
o
= 0
, the normal force is determined by

If the slider is slowly lifted from the driving rod, inertial forces can be neglected. At lift-off,
F

F

F

. If the slider is further lifted from the driving rod, the magnetic attraction force and, thus,
F

F

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p:
Two different driving rods are investigated. One rod was used before in other motor experiments and is found to be slightly magnetized. The other rod is unused and additionally demagnetized before the experiments. Sliders with friction pads from aluminium and alumina (
A
l
2
O
3
) are used in the experiments, both with a load of two magnets. Seven measurements with a vertically aligned rod (
α =
90
∘
) are taken for each setup. Table 1 contains the identified mean values and sample standard deviations.

caption.p: Normal forces measured with different setups.

sec.p: Repeatability of the measurement procedure is found to be very good, with the sample standard deviation clearly below 1% of the mean value. Some measurements taken at different positions along and around the rod are compared. They show only small differences, with the mean values differing by a maximum of about 1%. All these deviations are a lot smaller than the difference observed between the two rods.

Comparing the results in Table 1 with the gravitational force of 13.7 mN exerted by the slider of mass 1.4 g shows that gravitation has only a minor effect on the contact forces in the investigated setup also at non-vertical operation, that is, with
| α | ≠
90
∘
.

sec.title: Indirect measurement of friction force
sec.p: One general rule for the identification of parameters of friction contacts is that the conditions in the measurement setup should be as close to the operating conditions of the friction contact as possible (Bergander and Breguet, 2002), because even for the same friction partners, the friction coefficient can change significantly with measurement conditions (Blau, 1992). Therefore, the actual motor described earlier is used for identifying the parameters of the friction contact.

To directly measure the friction force, a sensor must be attached to driving rod or slider, making measurement during normal motor operation impossible. The alternative is to use an indirect approach that does not require modification of the system, calculating the friction force from its measured effect. This section and the next section ‘Direct measurement of friction force’ describe measurements with these two different approaches.

Applying the equation of motion of the slider, the friction force can be calculated from the slider acceleration
x
¨
s

All results and parameters described in the following are for experiments with the
A
l
2
O
3
slider with two magnets also used in the normal force measurements.

sec.title: Experimental setup
sec.p:
The slider acceleration cannot be measured directly using an accelerometer because the smallest accelerometer known to the authors has a size similar to that of the slider. Its mass and the attached wire would disturb the slider movement and probably prevent proper motor operation. Also, a non-magnetic accelerometer would have to be used in order not to influence the magnetic attraction between slider and rod. Thus, the slider velocity is measured contactlessly with a laser vibrometer and then numerically differentiated to get the acceleration. The slider mass is determined as
m
s
= 1 . 4
g
using precision scales, and the gravity constant is
g = 9 . 81
m /
s
2
. A second laser vibrometer is used to measure the velocity of the driving rod. This allows to investigate the relationship between relative velocity and friction force.

The actuator is driven using a superposition of two sinusoidal voltage signals with a frequency relation of 1:2. This type of signal has been used for inertia motors by other researchers (Bansevicius and Blechertas, 2008; Nishimura and Morita, 2010) and is effectively an approximation of the often desired ‘sawtooth’ signal with two terms of a Fourier series. Compared to an ideal sawtooth, this signal can be amplified more easily without distortion and it does not contain high-frequency components that could excite undesired vibrations. In order to avoid any undesired sticking that could take place during a phase of zero slope, the amplitude of the higher frequency sine signal is reduced from 1/2 to 1/3 of the lower frequency amplitude.1Figure 6 shows normalized rising and falling sawtooth signals, their Fourier series approximation and its modification for use in the measurements. In the following, the frequency
f
1
=
ω
1
/ 2 π = 1 /
T
1
of the lower frequency sine is referred to as the excitation frequency. The driving signal from an arbitrary waveform generator is amplified to a range of −20 to +140 V in the experiment.

caption.p: Rising and falling ideal sawtooth signals (solid), Fourier series approximation (dotted) and signals used in the measurements (dashed).

sec.p:
Because the driving rod is oriented vertically, gravity supports the motion of the slider in one direction and opposes it in the other direction. In order to make the slider finish its movement approximately in its starting position, allowing frequent repetition without manual repositioning, 10 periods of the rising ‘sawtooth’ signal are applied, followed by a pause of length
T
1
and five periods of the falling signal. Before the measurements, several periods of the rising and falling signal are applied alternatingly for running-in, making the slider move up and down over the length of the driving rod.

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p: The upper diagram in Figure 7 shows the displacement of rod and slider for an excitation frequency of 1 kHz. The lower diagram shows the friction force calculated from the slider acceleration according to equation (7).

caption.p:
Measured displacement of rod (dotted) and slider (solid) (upper diagram) and friction force calculated from slider acceleration (lower diagram) for
f
1
= 1
kHz
.

sec.p: Even though the displacement signals are very smooth and show little noise, the friction force calculated from the acceleration signal is very noisy. The reason for this is that laser vibrometry directly measures velocity. This (noisy) signal is then either integrated to get the displacement or differentiated to get the acceleration. Integration reduces noise, and differentiation amplifies it. The force signal shown in Figure 7 has been passed through a floating average filter over 14 µs. Stronger filtering is critical because the steep flanks in the force signal indicating the direction change of the friction force must be preserved. At higher excitation frequencies, noise increases even further and parameter identification becomes even more difficult; thus, only the results of the measurement at 1 kHz are presented here.

The peaks of the force when it changes direction could describe the maximum static friction force. However, the peaks are very short and their height varies, so a value for the coefficient of static friction
μ
s
is hard to determine.

In order to identify a value for the coefficient of dynamic friction
μ
d
, the average sliding friction force is determined by averaging all readings with an absolute value between two boundaries, here chosen as 0.07 and 0.25 N. Figure 7 contains these boundaries as dashed lines. From equation (6) and with the normal force
F
¯
n
= 507
mN
, as derived earlier,
μ
d
is determined as 0.157 for positive forces, meaning upward motion, and as 0.165 for downward motion. The mean relative velocity for sliding friction as defined earlier is found to be 36.0 mm/s for upward motion and 49.5 mm/s for downward motion.

sec.title: Experimental setup
sec.p:
Figure 8 shows the setup for direct measurement of the friction force together with a schematic representation. Again, the original motor configuration is used. The motor is mounted on the positioning stage also used in the measurement of normal force, with the driving rod aligned horizontally (
α =
0
∘
). A force sensor with a wooden stinger attached to it is mounted opposing the motor so that the stinger tip can contact the centre of the slider face. With a differential laser vibrometer (OFV-512 with controller OFV-5000, both from Polytec GmbH, Germany), the relative displacement between slider and rod is measured. The force sensor obstructs the ideal path for the laser beams. They therefore hit the measurement points under a certain small angle
β
from the normal direction. The same angle is used for both beams, and the small measurement error introduced by the beam angle is then compensated by multiplying the measured values with
cos
β
, assuming movement only in the normal direction. The following procedure is repeated for each measurement:

list-item.p: The positioning stage is manually moved slowly to the left until there is contact between stinger and slider. Contact is detected by observing when the force signal changes to a non-zero value.

The actuator is driven by one period of a versed sine voltage signal, making it extend and contract. In the extension phase, the slider slides on the rod because it is held by the stinger. In the contraction phase, the slider moves back with the rod.

caption.p: Setup for direct friction force measurement: photograph and schematic.

sec.p:
A series of measurements is made with different periods of the versed sine signal of T = 1, 0.1 and 0.01 s. The measurements with
T = 0 . 01
s
are distorted by large vibrations and thus discarded.

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p: Figure 9 displays the measured friction force plotted over the relative displacement and the relative velocity. The plot over displacement shows that

list-item.p: The measured force is relatively steady compared to the indirect friction measurement.

There is a slight dependence of the friction force on the position along the driving rod – characteristic shapes of the force plots shift along the x-axis as the slider moves along the rod from measurement to measurement.

The coefficient of static friction
μ
s
is not or only slightly larger than
μ
d
. The difference is not significantly larger than the variation of
μ
d
with position.

caption.p:
Friction force measured at cosine periods of
T = 0 . 1
s
(black) and T = 1 s (grey), plotted over (a) relative displacement and (b) Magnified portion of (a). (c) relative velocity, illustrating the determination of the tangential stiffness
σ
0
of one friction contact:
σ
0
= 80
mN / 0 . 21
μ m = 381
kN / m
.

sec.p:
To determine an average coefficient of friction, a relative velocity above which the friction partners are regarded to be sliding is defined and the measured values above this threshold are averaged. For
T = 1
s
,
μ
d
is determined as 0.141 at a mean relative velocity of 117 µm/s; for
T = 0 . 1
s
,
μ
d
is determined as 0.149 at a mean relative velocity of 878 µm/s. Together with the results from the indirect friction measurements and the plot of friction force over velocity in Figure 9, this supports the assumption that
μ
d
is slightly velocity dependent.

From the slope of the returning path in Figure 9(a), an average tangential stiffness of the friction contact of
σ
0
≈ 400
kN
/ m
is found. The break-away force is
F
s
≈ 0 . 15 N
. This results in a characteristic displacement of
s ≈ 0 . 35
μ m
according to equation (1). As the actuator displacement is almost two orders of magnitude larger than
s
, Altpeter’s condition for the use of kinetic friction models is clearly fulfilled.

sec.title: Numerical simulation
sec.p:
A one-dimensional model of a rigid slider of mass
m
s
, driven by the gravitational force
F
g
=
m
s
g
and by the friction force
F
f
, is simulated numerically. Its equation of motion is

The following three different classic friction models for calculating the friction force
F
f
( t )
are implemented:

list-item.p:
Pure Coulomb friction, that is, sliding only with constant
μ
d
, using

Coulomb friction with sticking,
μ
s
=
μ
d
, using

Coulomb friction with sticking,
μ
s
>

, also using equation (10)

sec.p:
The numerical model is implemented in MATLAB and takes the measured motion of the driving rod (
x
r
( t )
,
x
·
r
( t )
,
x
¨

( t )
) as an input. It numerically solves the differential equation (8) using the solver ode45 and returns the motion of the slider (
x
s
( t )
,
x
·

( t )
,
x
¨

( t )
). The measured signals are filtered with a low-pass filter with a cut-off frequency of 50 kHz (Butterworth, eighth order) before they are fed into the numerical model. Without filtering, acceleration spikes caused by measurement noise lead to unrealistic simulation results.

For the dynamic friction coefficient, two values are tested:
0 . 161
, the mean value from the indirect friction measurements and
0 . 141
, the value identified for very low relative velocity in the direct friction force measurements. A coefficient of static friction
μ
s
cannot be clearly identified from the measurements shown earlier, but it is clear that
μ
s
is not or only slightly higher than
μ
d
in the investigated setup. So
μ
s
= 1 . 1
μ
d
was assumed for model 3. Vertical motion (
α =
90
∘
) is simulated, and thus, a contact force of
F
¯
n
= 507
mN
as measured before for the investigated setup was used in the calculation.

sec.title: Comparison of simulation and experimental results
sec.p:
To analyse the quality of the numerical model, the measurements made for the indirect determination of the friction force are used. Figure 10 shows the measurement and the simulation results for friction models 1 (sliding only) and 3 (sliding and sticking,
μ
s
= 1 . 1
μ
d
) for the excitation frequencies f1 = 1, 1.5 and 2 kHz. The simulated slider motion for model 2 (sliding and sticking,
μ
s
=
μ
d
) is very similar to that for model 3 under all conditions and therefore not shown in Figure 10 for the sake of clarity.

caption.p:
Measured rod and slider motion and simulated slider motion with different models (Coulomb friction without and with sticking, both for
μ
d
= 0 . 141
and for
μ
d
= 0 . 161
) for different excitation frequencies.

sec.p: For all frequencies shown, all investigated simple friction models qualitatively reproduce the measured motion. But none of the models is able to reproduce the experimental data quantitatively well enough to be used for performance estimation and parameter optimization. Of the parameters studied, the excitation frequency has the largest influence on the fit between simulation and experiment. For the three frequencies shown in Figure 10, there is a tendency for the model to overestimate the slider motion at lower frequencies and to underestimate it at higher frequencies.

A change of the friction model has only a small impact on the simulation result, and the difference between the three models reaches a maximum of 3%. A main reason for this is that the friction contact is in sliding regime most of the time, so that the difference between the friction models has little effect. Changing the value of
μ
d
has a slightly larger effect on the simulation results than a change of the friction model.

sec.title: Measurement of rod vibration
sec.p:
The observed deviations of the slider motion between experiment and simulation cannot be explained by deficiencies of the friction models. Nonlinear phenomena not represented in kinetic friction models should not have a significant influence according to Altpeter’s condition and also could not explain the large difference in the model fit between different excitation frequencies. Experimental data indicate a possible small influence of the relative velocity on
μ
d
that is not modelled, but this influence is too small to have an effect large enough to explain the observed deviations. These deviations must therefore result from another assumption made in the model – regarding the driving rod as a rigid body moving only in axial direction. The motion along the rod is measured for different excitation signals to investigate possible unmodelled vibrations.

sec.title: Experimental setup
sec.p:
For exciting the piezoelectric actuator, the same setup as in the experiments described earlier is used. The three-dimensional (3D) motion of 11 points along the actuator, adapter piece and driving rod is measured with a 3D laser vibrometer (CLV-3000 from Polytec GmbH, Germany). The driving rod is aligned horizontally (
α = 0
) during these measurements. Figure 11 introduces the coordinate system used for the measurements, where
z ′
points vertically upwards and
y ′
is horizontal and perpendicular to the rod axis. The points where velocities have been measured are marked and numbered in Figure 11.

caption.p: Measured points and coordinates, seen from above.

sec.p: The measured velocities are numerically integrated, and the obtained displacement signal is run through a linear phase bandpass filter in order to eliminate low-frequency drift and high-frequency noise.
The actuator is driven with the sawtooth approximation used in the friction experiments at base frequencies from 0.5 to 2.5 kHz.

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p: Figures 12 and 13 show displacement time series and projections of the trajectories of the 11 points in the xy′, xz′ and y′z′ planes for excitation with f1 = 1 and 2 kHz, respectively. In each trajectory diagram, axes are equally scaled in order to visualize the vibration magnitude relations.

caption.p:
Time series (upper left part) and projections of averaged point trajectories in the xy′, xz′ and y′z′ planes for
f
1
= 1
kHz
.

Time series (upper left part) and projections of averaged point trajectories in the xy′, xz′ and y′z′ planes for
f
1
= 2
kHz
.

sec.p: The magnitude of the desired vibration in x direction is approximately proportional to the excitation amplitude but only roughly equal at the different points. This is important as in the numerical simulations, the motion measured at the rod tip, close to point 1, was assumed to be the same for all points along the rod.
At 0.5 kHz, lateral vibrations in y′- and z′ directions are existent, but relatively small compared to the main vibration. They become larger at 1 kHz and further increase for rising frequency.

The time series of the lateral vibrations in y′ and z′ directions in Figure 13– despite the fluctuating signals – shows that the amplitude is largest for the points on the actuator and then steadily decreases to some point after which it increases again, but phase-shifted by 180. This can be caused by bending vibration with a node somewhere around points 3–6. But displacement in y′ and z′ directions can also be caused by a rod that is rigid, but not perfectly aligned in x direction.

The peak-to-peak excitation amplitude for f1 = 0.5 and 1 kHz is 34 V. To avoid unreproducible vibrations, it had to be reduced to 24, 14.3 and 5.5 V for f1 = 1.5, 2 and 2.5 kHz, respectively. The stack of disc springs that apply the pre-stress to the piezoelectric actuator is assumed to be the main reason why high excitation amplitudes cause unreproducible vibration: When the actuator contracts with high acceleration, they are not able to follow the actuator motion, lose contact and vibrate in an uncontrolled fashion. This assumption is supported by the fact that the amplitude at which chaotic vibration occurred is different for rising and falling sawtooth signals.

sec.title: Influence of lateral vibrations on the friction contact
sec.p:
The influence of lateral vibrations on the friction contact is investigated first for vibrations in z direction, that is, in the direction of total normal force, compare Figure 5. Assuming that rod and slider stay in contact,
F
~
n
, the vibration-induced normal force at each of the two contacts, can be described by

The total normal force is the sum of the static normal force resulting from magnetic attraction and gravity equation (2), and
F
~
n
. In the friction measurements, the slider was positioned roughly in the middle of the driving rod, around points 2–5. For these points, a maximum acceleration amplitude of approximately 250 m/s2 at
f
1
= 1 . 5
kHz
is found, resulting in

This acceleration was measured at a peak-to-peak excitation amplitude of 24 V, but the indirect friction force measurements were taken at a peak-to-peak excitation amplitude of 160 V. Lateral vibrations can be assumed to increase approximately linearly with excitation amplitude. If the magnitudes of the static normal force – see Table 1– and its vibration-induced modulation are compared, it is clear that the latter cannot be neglected.

The influence of vibrations in y direction is more difficult to describe. They increase the normal force on one of the friction pads and equally decrease it on the other pad. As the slider is effectively driven by the sum of the two forces, vibrations in y direction are likely to have a much smaller influence on the friction force in x direction. But if they reach a certain level, they can lead to rotation of the slider around the driving rod because the centre of mass of the slider is not in the centre plane of the rod.

sec.title: Summary and conclusion
sec.p: An experimental setup for measuring the contact force in an inertia motor and two setups for measuring friction force and relative displacement in the same motor were presented. The investigated motor consists of a pre-stressed multilayer piezoelectric actuator driving a steel rod on which a slider with aluminium or alumina friction pads moves, pressed against the rod by magnetic attraction. The presented setup was shown to measure the contact force for different friction pads and magnets precisely and with very good repeatability.

In one setup for friction force measurement, friction force is not measured directly, but calculated from the motion of the slider during motor operation. This measurement method works and delivers usable results, but suffers from very noisy force signals especially at operating frequencies above 1 kHz. In the second setup for friction force measurement, motion of the slider is suppressed in one direction by a force sensor with a stinger attached to it. This setup allows precise measurement of static and dynamic friction forces, but can only be used at frequencies far below the typical operation frequencies of inertia motors.

For the investigated motor, the coefficients of dynamic friction identified from the different experiments slightly increase for increasing mean relative velocity. The coefficient of static friction is not significantly higher than the coefficient of dynamic friction.

A condition for the applicability of simply kinetic friction models for the simulation of inertia motors postulated by Altpeter (1999) was shown to be well fulfilled for the investigated motor. The friction contact in the motor is therefore simulated using different simple friction models. All investigated friction models qualitatively reproduce the measured motion, but show quantitative deviations varying with excitation frequency. An experimental investigation of driving rod vibrations that are not represented in the numerical model shows that the displacement in axial direction is not constant along the rod, and that there are lateral vibrations that significantly influence the contact force and therefore the slider motion.

The proposed methods for identifying the parameters of simple friction models in inertia motors are usable, but need improvement to cover the relevant frequency range more reliably. Possible improvements could aim at decreasing the noise of the acceleration signal for the indirect friction force measurement or increasing the maximum operating frequency of the setup for direct force measurement.

Simple kinetic friction models are very likely to simulate the friction contact in a lot of inertia motors well enough for practical purposes. The deviations observed in the presented simulations can be attributed to the unmodelled vibrations of the investigated motor. It appears that undesired or neglected vibrations are the main factor hindering agreement between measurements and simple models for piezoelectric inertia drives with step sizes in the range of micrometres and larger. Possible directions for future motor development to be drawn from this conclusion could be the reduction of undesired vibrations and the development of drive signals that either are very robust to lateral vibrations or that can use them advantageously, for example, to increase and decrease the contact force periodically.

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial or not-for-profit sectors.
Nishimura et al. (2012) have recently made a similar step, reducing the amplitude of the higher frequency signal from 1/2 of the lower frequency amplitude in their 2010 article to 1/4.
